mainmatter.p: PhD Student at the University of Birmingham.

A ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-locale X is called spectral if it satisfies the following three conditions.
It is a compact locale (i.e. the empty meet is compact).
The meet of two compact opens is compact.
For every U : \mathcal{O} ( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal{W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
(K_U, \kappa _U) gives U as its join.
It consists of compact opens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf{isCompactOpen} ( \kappa _{U}(k)).

Notice the relationship of the third condition here to pseudocontinuity. If we formulate a notion of ‚Äúpseudoalgebraicity‚Äù i.e. the analogue of pseudocontinuity for algebraicity, we could use that avoid the repetition here. This is not good for presentation purposes, however, so it should probably be recorded as an equivalence.

A ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-locale X is called zero-dimensional if it satisfies the following condition: for every U : \mathcal{O} ( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal{W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
(K_U, \kappa _U) gives U as its join.
It consists of clopens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf{isClopen} ( \kappa _{U}(k)).

A ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-locale X is called spectral if it satisfies the following three conditions.
It is a compact locale (i.e. the empty meet is compact).
The meet of two compact opens is compact.
For every U : \mathcal{O} ( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal{W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
(K_U, \kappa _U) gives U as its join.
It consists of compact opens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf{isCompactOpen} ( \kappa _{U}(k)).

A ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-locale X is called zero-dimensional if it satisfies the following condition: for every U : \mathcal{O} ( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal{W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
(K_U, \kappa _U) gives U as its join.
It consists of clopens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf{isClopen} ( \kappa _{U}(k)).

In Tom de Jong's thesis and his Agda formalization of domain theory, the term ‚Äústructurally continuous‚Äù is used to mean a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D, is called structurally continuous if it is equipped with a function giving, for every x : D, a small directed family of elements way below x giving x as its join.
In the new terminology, this notion of ‚Äústructure‚Äù involved in the continuity of a dcpo is made explicit by the following notion.

A continuity datum for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
The element x is the supremum of (K_x, \kappa _x).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.

Factoring this structure out into a definition of its own obviates the need to have a name for the notion of a ‚Äú\mathcal{V}-dcpo having a specified continuity datum‚Äù. Even though the equivalence between structurally continuous and ‚Äúhaving a specified continuity datum‚Äù is completely trivial, we still record this in the following proposition to be able to explicitly refer to this terminological identity.

frontmatter.meta: Defn 4.4.1 of de Jong's PhD thesis

mainmatter.p: A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D having a specified continuity datum is the same thing as D being structurally continuous.

By replacing the specified existence here with mere existence, we obtain the notion of a continuous \mathcal{V}-dcpo. The terminology for this is unchanged (i.e. the same as the terminology of Tom de Jong's thesis).
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo is called continuous if there exists a continuity datum for it.

A pseudocontinuous \mathcal{V}-dcpo is the same thing as a \mathcal{V}-dcpo with a specified continuity datum, but with the requirement of a specified directed \mathcal{V}-family (given by the continuity datum) weakened to a requirement of mere existence.

An intensional continuous basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) with the further requirement that for every x : D, the directed \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) given by the basis satisfies the condition \forall k : K_x. \ \beta ( \kappa _x(k)) \ll x.
An extensional continuous basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional continuous basis that is extensional

An algebraicity datum for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D that satisfies the following.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
The element x is the supremum of (K_x, \kappa _x).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) is compact.

Similar to the case of a continuity datum, we record the terminological identity between a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D being ‚Äústructurally algebraic‚Äù (the terminology from de Jong's thesis) and it having a specified algebraicity datum.
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D having a specified algebraicity datum is the same thing as D being structurally algebraic.
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if there exists an algebraicity datum for it.

Let D be a \mathcal{V}-dcpo and define the type K_x \vcentcolon \equiv \sum _{c : D} \mathsf{compact} ( c ) \times c \sqsubseteq x of compact opens below a given x : D. The \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if it satisfies the following conditions.
For every x : D, K_x is \mathcal{V}-small.
The \mathcal{V}-family (K_x, \mathsf{pr} _1 ) is directed with supremum x.
An intensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) satisfying \forall b : B. \ \mathsf{compact} ( \beta (b) ) .
An extensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is an intensional algebraic basis (B, \beta ) that is extensional.
In our presentation here, we decouple the notion of a basis for a \mathcal{V}-dcpo from any kind of compactness or relative compactness requirements.

In the context of domain theory, the natural notion of basis should include such requirements (see for example Defn. 2.2.3 of Abramsky and Jung). As our presentation here is intended to be applicable to a class of lattices broader than that of dcpos, however, we attempt to keep the presentation free of bias towards a specific attitude. This is our motivation for the aforementioned decoupling.

When the notion of a \mathcal{V}-dcpo attains a specific attitude, such as that of a denotational domain, it is perfectly fine for these terms to be overloaded to refer to concepts that include these requirements.

Let D be a \mathcal{V}-dcpo. An intensional basis for D is a \mathcal{V}-family (B, \beta ) on D satisfying the condition: for every element x : D, there is a specified directed \mathcal{V}-family (I_x, \iota _x) on the basis index B such that x = \bigvee (I_x, \beta \circ \iota _x).
Let D be a \mathcal{V}-dcpo. An intensional basis (B, \beta ) for D is called an extensional basis if \beta is an embedding.
Let D be a \mathcal{V}-dcpo. An intensional basis (B, \beta ) for D is called an extensional basis if \beta is an embedding.

Let D be a \mathcal{V}-dcpo. An intensional basis for D is a \mathcal{V}-family (B, \beta ) on D satisfying the condition: for every element x : D, there is a specified directed \mathcal{V}-family (I_x, \iota _x) on the basis index B such that x = \bigvee (I_x, \beta \circ \iota _x).
A locale X is called large and locally small if it is given by a ( \mathcal{U} ^+, \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{U} )-frame.
The following is the summary of my understanding of Longley and Normann's discussion in Section 3.2.1 of their book on higher-order computability.
Consider a function F : \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} } \to \mathbb{N}, that is computable in an intuitive sense.

Given some g \in \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} }, when the function F returns a result F(g) \in \mathbb{N}, it must do so after a finite examination of the input g. This is to say that there must be some r \in \mathbb{N} such that F "looks at" only the values g(0), \ldots , g(i_{r-1}). So the result F(g) is determined solely using the information of the behaviour of g on the inputs 0, \ldots , i_{r-1}.

Attempting to capture this idea of F being determined solely on a finite amount of information about the behaviour of g, we are naturally led to the notion of continuity: F cannot distinguish between g and any other function g' \in \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} } that returns the same values as those of g on inputs 0, \ldots , i_{r-1}. In other words, \forall g' \in \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} } . \ \forall k \in \{ 0, \ldots , r-1 \} . \ g(i_k) = g'(i_k) \rightarrow F(g) = F(g').

This is precisely the same thing as saying that F is continuous with respect to the standard Baire topology on \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} } and the discrete topology \mathbb{N}. Continuity is merely a necessary condition for computability as there are many continuous functions F : \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} } \to \mathbb{N} that are not computable (in any sense). The idea, however, is that an abstract model of computation based only on this necessary condition will already capture some interesting aspects of computability.

If F : \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} } \to \mathbb{N} is continuous in this sense, the function F can be described completely by whether the information g(0) = m_0, \ldots , g(r-1) = m-1 is sufficient to determine the value of F(g), and if it is, what this value is. But this information that completely determines F is finite and itself be represented as a function f_F \in \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} }, defined as f( \langle m_0, \ldots , m_{r-1} \rangle ) \vcentcolon \equiv \begin{cases} m + 1 & \mathsf{if} \ g(0) = m_0 \wedge \cdots \wedge g(r-1) = m_{r-1} \rightarrow F(g) = m \ \\ 0 & \mathsf{if} \ g(0) = m_0 \wedge \cdots \wedge g(r-1) = m_{r-1} \ \mathsf{does \ not \ suffice \ to \ determine} \ F(g) \end{cases}

The idea of the partial application operation is to take such an f_F encoding a function F : \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} } \to \mathbb{N} and to determine the value of F(g) using the continuity data encoded by f_F. This brings us to the definition of this application operation.

Let
\langle {-} \rangle denote some computable coding operation \mathsf{List} ( \mathbb{N} ) \to \mathbb{N}, and
\mu denote the minimization operator.

Given two functions f, g : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}, the application of f to g is defined as follows: f \ | \ g \quad \vcentcolon \equiv \quad f( \langle g(0), \ldots , g(r - 1) \rangle ) where r \vcentcolon \equiv \mu r. \ f( \langle g(0), \ldots , g(r - 1) \rangle ) > 0
Defined in Section 3.2.1 of Longley and Normann's book.
So this operation gives us a function {-} \ | \ {-} : \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} } \times \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} } \rightharpoonup \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} }
Kleene's second model (often denoted \mathsf{K_2}) is the structure ( \mathbb{N} ^{ \mathbb{N} } , {-} \ | \ {-} ).
Kleene's countable functionals extend this idea from types of degree 2 to types of arbitrary degree i.e. higher types.

frontmatter.title: Frame (type-theoretic)
frontmatter.meta: Defn. 2.4 from Patch Locale of a Spectral Locale in Univalent Type Theory

mainmatter.p:
A ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-frame L consists of a
a type |L| : \mathcal{U}
a partial order - \le - : |L| \to |L| \to \Omega _{ \mathcal{V} },
a top element \mathbf{1} : |L|,
an operation - \wedge - : |L| \to |L| \to |L| giving the greatest lower bound U \wedge V of any two U, V : |L|.
an operation \bigvee - : \mathsf{Fam} _{ \mathcal{W} }(|L|) \to |L| giving the least upper bound \bigvee _{i : I} U_i of any \mathcal{W}-family \left \{ U_i \right \} _{i : I}.
such that binary meets distribute over arbitrary joins, i.e. U \wedge \bigvee _{i : I} V_i = \bigvee _{i : I} U \wedge V_i for every U : |L| and \mathcal{W}-family \{ V_i \} _{i : I} in |L|.

frontmatter.title: Intuition on the notion of a domain

mainmatter.p: In the words of Mart√≠n Escard√≥: A domain is a set of concrete finite elements together with infinite, ideal elements such that the ideal elements are characterised uniquely by their finite approximations.
There are different ways of capturing this mathematically, to varying degrees of precision. These include continuous and algebraic dcpos.

frontmatter.title: Patch Locale of a Spectral Locale in Univalent Type Theory

mainmatter.p: This is an example tree in my forest.
